instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.P5VG3S_EN: What is P5VG3S_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_G3S power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PPBUS_3GH: What is PPBUS_3GH? PPBUS_3GH is a typo of PPBUS_G3H. If you see someone type PPBUS_3GH assume they meant to type PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead after water damage.
threads.message:
Hi,
the board came to me after cleaning and repair try. 
Fan work for a 2-3 sec.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_3GH</SIGNAL> - 12.3V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P5VG3S</SIGNAL> - 12.3V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>- EVERY 5 SECOUND SHOW 5V FOR A SECOUND then 0v
<SIGNAL>P5VG3S_EN</SIGNAL> - EVERY 5 SECOUND SHOW 1V-3.4V FOR A SECOUND.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>- 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4SW</SIGNAL> -0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> - 2.4V STABLE BUT EVERY 5 SECOUND SHOW 5V FOR A SECOUND.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead after water damage.
threads.message:
Looks like power cycle every 5s.
Search for short all secondary power rails; big coils and page 78.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead after water damage.
threads.message:
You can have a short on a secondary voltage.
Did you try SMC bypass?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead after water damage.
threads.message:
You MUST maintain power button pressed 5-10s, after charger was connected.
Do not release the button faster.

"explain please"
All pages 68-78...

PP0V8 - short
PP1V2 - 112 OHM

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead after water damage.
threads.message:
"PP0V8 - short"
Do you mean <SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>?
Bad news then.
Remove <CAPACITOR>C7905</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C4423</CAPACITOR> and check again.
If still short, then bad T2 chip.

<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>  is 212ohm
<SIGNAL>PP0V82_SLPDDR</SIGNAL> is short
